entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies series: Don't fly blind (Stress to strength: Mindful living in work & beyond)
entry.content:
Thanks to Moshe

First of all, a heartfelt thank you to  @moshenaveh , who initiated this wonderful blog series about hobbies in the SAP Community. His post “Mind your step” about walking and hiking not only inspired me, but also showed me how closely movement, nature, and inner peace are connected. Hiking and running have also been passions of mine for many years. But one special experience led me onto a new path: the path of yoga. Today I combine both movement in nature and on the yoga mat, combined with mindfulness, conscious breathing, and inner clarity.

Me on a mindful hike near Austria wearing a hat.

Who I am

My name is Achim Toeper, and I have been part of the SAP world for more than three decades. My professional journey has taken me deep into technology and leadership – but at the same time I discovered another passion: yoga and mindfulness. Since completing my yoga teacher training in 2018, these practices have become an integral part of my life. They give me energy, inspiration, and a new way of engaging with people in projects, teams, and communities. From this connection, personal projects where born, in which I combine movement, mindfulness, and leadership skills, like writing and talking about it.

My path to yoga

Some years ago, I found myself in an extremely intense professional period, marked by great responsibility and pressure. The stress kept growing – and I realized that I needed a counterbalance to avoid burning out. In this search, I came across yoga for the first time in a wellness hotel in the Allgäu – at exactly the moment when I needed it the most. This experience truly flashed me: I immediately felt that yoga is more than just movement. During those very days, I knew I wanted to dive deeper and one day become a yoga teacher myself. Step by step I learned how to regain strength through conscious breathing, movement, and meditation. Yoga gave me not only calm and balance, but also a new perspective on leadership, collaboration, and on myself.

Yoga class and ice bathing in the Ore Mountains 2014

A special moment in Copenhagen

Since that first encounter, yoga has become a constant part of my life. In 2018 I had the opportunity to bring my passion into a very special setting at the SAP Community Event in Copenhagen. At the end of my talk, I sat down cross-legged on stage while the audience remained in their seats. Behind me, an animated GIF was running in my presentation, visualizing the rhythm of box breathing:
inhale for four seconds, hold for four seconds, exhale for four seconds, hold for four seconds.
Together we followed this rhythm – and for a moment the large conference room became completely silent. Everyone was connected through the same breathing pattern. This experience was surprising for many and deeply moving for me: a moment where technology, community, and mindfulness came together in a very powerful way. 



A special honor for me on World Mental Health Day

Another highlight was October 10th 2023, the international World Mental Health Day. On this day, I was invited to lead an international yoga session for my company. People from different countries and time zones came together virtually to breathe, move, and pause for a moment. For me it was a great honor and at the same time a confirmation that mindfulness and yoga go far beyond private practice – they can build bridges, create community, and have a tangible impact in a global professional environment.

What yoga means to me

For me, yoga is far more than physical exercises. It is an attitude that shapes everyday life – both professionally and personally. It reminds me that behind every role and function there is always a human being. This perspective has changed my leadership style: away from pure control, towards more trust, calmness, and leading by example. In my company, some colleagues jokingly call me “Yoda” – a nice sign that mindfulness not only brings calm but also inspiration. For me, yoga is a compass that helps me stay clear, human, and connected even in challenging situations.

Practicing Vrksasana Yoga “Tree Pose” on a hike.

Running, swimming, and the strength of connecting with others

Back in 2000, I joined a group mainly consisting of triathletes and hockey players. That was the moment I finally started running – something I had enjoyed before but never really practiced regularly.
My last major run was in 2014 in Vienna, a city that holds a special place in my heart.

Last year – as well as this year – I completed an Olympic triathlon. Swimming has always had a calming effect on me, running grounds me in the here and now, and the combination of all three disciplines teaches me perseverance, humility, and trust in my own body.

I remember well the SAP Community Event in Copenhagen in May 2018 – that’s where I met @smarchesini .
Sebastiano is not only someone who drives SAP topics forward, but also someone who shares his passion for running with others.
I am delighted that he will be next in this hobbies series – because running connects us, and I am sure his story will bring fresh inspiration.

Photo of me taken during a race at a multi-generational run

Join the conversation

Do you do Yoga or Meditation? Share the pictures and stories behind them in the comments section. Feel free to share other hobbies you have!

If you're interested in joining the series, please reach out to Moshe Naveh via community@sap.com.

Let's get this journey going! I hope you all enjoy the great posts coming-up!

entry.title: Вебкасти Жовтня
entry.content:
SAP Вебкасти Жовтня 2025: Частина 1 🚀

Перша половина жовтня насичена безкоштовними вебкастами від SAP - AI, трансформація, data та галузеві рішення!

📅 Найближчі заходи:

1 жовтня, 15:00-19:00 🔹 Product Compliance Solution Update Demos & Customer Stories: стратегія, roadmap та панельні дискусії з EHS та Product Compliance

1 жовтня, 17:00-18:00 🔹 AI in Asset Management Як AI трансформує управління активами: intelligent insights та автоматизоване прийняття рішень

2 жовтня, 15:00-19:00 🔹 Environmental Health & Safety Solutions What's New and What's Next у EHS та Product Compliance

2 жовтня, 17:00-18:00 🔹 AI in Service Management Революція в сервісному управлінні: AI-driven оптимізація та кращий клієнтський досвід

7 жовтня, 15:00-16:00 🔹 Introduction to Clean Core Strategy Модернізація ERP-ландшафту: як зменшити складність та підготуватися до трансформації

8 жовтня, 18:00-19:00 🔹 SAP Business Data Cloud: Module 3 Create and Enrich Analytical Model with SAP Datasphere - hands-on workshop 📌 Modules 1-2 доступні on demand!

9 жовтня, 17:00-18:00 🔹 Transforming Shopping Journeys Персоналізація та AI у роздрібній торгівлі: від product recommendations до AI-powered пошуку

14 жовтня, 15:00-16:00 🔹 Achieving Clean Core: Extensibility Clean Core Level концепція: KPI, governance та вибір правильних опцій розширюваності

14 жовтня, 16:00-17:00 🔹 SAP Analytics Cloud Transforming SAP's End-to-End Planning Processes: досвід SAP IT у створенні інтегрованої платформи

14 жовтня, 17:00-18:00 🔹 SAP Service Cloud V2 - Q3/2025 Release Utilities та Enterprise Service Management: нові фічі та інтеграції

15 жовтня, 18:00-19:00 🔹 SAP Joule for Consultants AI-асистент для консультантів: як підвищити продуктивність та ефективність проєктів

*Всі години вказані за київським часом.

Якщо цей допис був корисним — ставте kudos!

Реєструйтесь вже зараз, посилання в назві вебкасту

entry.title: New Developer Forums!
entry.content:
Since the platform migration last year so many of you have asked "Where is ABAP?" and "Where are the questions about ABAP?" - we heard you loud an clear. We are therefore thrilled to finally be able to answer your questions as we are launching new Developer forums today!

 

This will be the new home for our developers and technical audience in the SAP Community, and we are starting with forums on the following topics: 

  • ABAP: Forum for everything about classic ABAP development, as well as all ABAP Cloud related topics, including ABAP Core Data Services (CDS), ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP), and ABAP for cloud development.
  • Artificial Intelligence : AI in general, SAP Business AI, Joule, Joule Agents, Joule for Consultants, Joule for Developers or AI Foundation.
  • SAP CAP: Everything on SAP Cloud Application Programming Model. 
  • Data and Analytics:
    • SAP Business Data Cloud, including Databricks, Datasphere, Analytics Cloud and Business Warehouse.
    • SAP HANA and SAP HANA Cloud.
    • SAP Master Data Governance.
  • Frontend / UI5 / SAP Fiori: All frontend-related topics, including SAPUI5, OpenUI5 and SAP Fiori. 
  • Integration: For all SAP Integration related topics. (not limited to SAP Integration Suite)
  • Tooling, including SAP Build: For all topics related to any SAP development tool, like SAP Build Code and ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse. 

But more than just launching a home for our developer/technical audience, we are also bringing back forums as a content type, including a more compact forum feed, threaded replies and not least a filter that many of you have requested for questions with no answers. We will get into the details of the new forums below 🙂 

All developer forums consist of a hub with options both for asking questions (forum) and for publishing blog posts: 

To be able to publish content in the forums, you first need to join the group/forum, therefore please make sure you hit the "Join Group" button: 

Joining the forum also automatically triggers a subscription to new content published in the group.
You can check or change your subscriptions and notifications in your account settings here. 

Forums

As mentioned above, we are bringing back forums as a content type. 
This first iteration of the new forum feed does not contain any preview of content, thus making it easier/faster for everyone to scroll down the list to identify the questions they might have an answer to. 
The feed gives you an overview over who asked the question, when it was published, and you can also see who replied to it last (and when), if there are replies. 
We also included a filter that many of you have requested, "No answers", which shows you all questions with no interaction. This is different to "No Solutions", as the no solutions filter will give you an overview over questions with an answer, but where the author has not yet accepted one of the answers as the right solution. 
Questions with a solution can easily be identified in the feed with the green checkmark to the left of the question. The second iteration of the forum feed will make it even easier to quickly identify questions with accepted solutions in the feed. 
We also kept the icons for views, answers/replies and kudos/views in the feed. 

 

Another change with forums, compared to the Q&As, is that we are bringing back threaded replies to questions. For forums there is no difference if it is a comment asking for clarification, or if you know the answer to the question. The correct answer can be found anywhere in the threaded conversation, and the author has the option to accept any answer as the correct solution to the question. 
As you can see in the screenshot below, it is not possible to accept any reply, anywhere in the conversation as the solution: 

 

When a question has an accepted solution, it will behave the same way as the Q&As. The question will have an "Go to solution" marker on top, and the accepted answer will be displayed directly below the question with a green checkmark and a green box to identify as the correct solution:

Other than joining the group, no special permissions is needed to ask your question in the forums. Even if you are new to the SAP Community, and come here to find help, you can do so immediately after creating a new account. 
As everywhere else in the Community, please do not answer questions with AI-generated content. If you don't know the answer, please move on to the next question where you know the answer, instead of trying to build a reputation by publishing AI-generated answers that do not add any value, and in many cases also are misleading or false. 

 

Blog posts

Blog posts in the developer forums will not have a separation between SAP employees and external community users. 
Although the forums will not be curated,  we will keep a close eye on what gets published to ensure the quality of the content is according to our guidelines. Blog posts in the SAP Community should be used to share value and your personal knowledge and expertise. 
The permissions to publish blog posts will follow the rank ladder system, so if you are new to community, your blog posts will be subject to moderation review. Community users who already have permissions to publish blog posts in the "Product and Technology" categories, will be able to publish blog posts directly in the new forums, without moderation. 
You can find more information on moderation in the SAP Community in this article in our Welcome Corner group. 

The "Featured Topics" section is curated by the SAP Community team for now, and will focus on highlighting important product updates that should not be missed. 

 

Pilot-phase

The launch today is a pilot, as we want to first see how you all respond before we make a final decision on whether or not forums are here to stay. The pilot will run for 3 months, until the end of the year. 

All forums start empty, with no published content. 
The exception is the three groups which we have moved over from the Interest groups, namely "Artificial Intelligence", "Data and Analytics", and "Integration" - these three groups were moved to the new Developers area with their content. 

We will over the next months continuously improve the user experience in the forums and forum feeds, and are as always open to feedback and suggestions. 

And one last thing. We have set the "Application Development and Automation" group to read only for now, to encourage everyone to participate here instead. We will decide what to do with the group and its content once this pilot has ended. 

The SAP Developer News posts from the SAP Developer Advocate team will be published here in the meantime. 

Happy foruming everyone! 🙂 

 

Known bugs

On the main forum page, the button still says "Start a Discussion", this will be changed to "Ask a question" as soon as possible: 

 

In the mobile portrait view of the forum feed, the last filter tab may break to another line in some cases. We are aware of this, and it will be fixed in one of our upcoming releases:

entry.title: Devtoberfest 2025 - What is happening Week 1
entry.content:
Hurray! Devtoberfest 2025 just launched. Let me welcome you to a full month of education, learning, networking and fun!

To give you a better overview on what is happening each week, I will release blog posts covering activities for each week.

It can be that we will assign points and badges retroactively for this week as we are currently facing issues. No worries, all activities are being monitored!

Sessions for Week 1 (Sep 29 - Oct 3):

All sessions for Week 1 can be found in our Session Catalogue: https://community.sap.com/t5/devtoberfest/eb-p/devtoberfest-events

🟢 ABAP (Monday)

  • Clean Core Extensibility Strategy Powered by ABAP Cloud and Generative AI
  • Custom code development and transformation for Clean Core in SAP S/4HANA
  • Boost Your Developer Satisfaction with SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI Capabilities

🟣 Tooling & Frontend (Tuesday)

  • Code-Along: Build a Joule Skill from Scratch with Joule Studio
  • Building Agents with Joule Studio
  • Unboxing Joule Studio: Honest Insights from Hack2Build Champions
  • Introducing Application Frontend: Simplifying UI App Hosting
  • Create a Case in Service Cloud V2 by Uploading Images Using AI Core, Build Apps

🔴Integration (Wednesday)

  • Accelerate your move to the cloud via Pipeline for Cloud Integration
  • Clean Core, Event-Driven: Unlocking SAP Value with Advanced Event Mesh
  • Designing understandable SAP BTP Solution Diagrams & contributing to the SAP Architecture Center
  • Open Resource Discovery – How to build a well-connected metadata catalog across silos

🔵Data & AI (Thursday)

  • Leveraging Calculation Views in SAP BAS: an Introduction
  • Enrich Data Products with SAP Databricks
  • Behind the Magic: How Cirque du Soleil Reimagined Invoice Management with SAP Business AI

🟠 CAP (Friday)

  • Building Enterprise Grade CAP applications using BTP Developer's guide
  • Get to know more about CAP’s documentation offering
  • Integrating S/4HANA Public Cloud APIs into CAP Made Simple

🟡 Community (Friday)

  • The New Developer Forums in the Community

Fun Activities - The Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt

In week 1, we are launching the new and challenging Scavenger Hunt! Find clues, put them together and gain a lot of points towards the Grand Prize!

For all information about the Scavenger Hunt, follow Daniel's blog post:
🟡 Fun for Week 1: The Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt 🔨🪙

Validation of your session participation

At Devtoberfest, almost every activity earns you points against the Grand Prize in our competition. This is the case for your participation in the Devtoberfest sessions for each week. Every week we release validation tutorials for the different topic tracks ABAP, Tooling & Frontend, Integration, Data & AI, CAP, and the Community sessions. The validation tutorials can be found in our Tutorial Navigator. 

It can be that we will assign points and badges retroactively for this week as we are currently facing issues. No worries, all activities are being monitored!

Head over to our tutorial page and complete the validation tutorials for earning your points!

entry.title: Ajudem estudantes a aprender como as empresas líderes utilizam a tecnologia SAP em processos
entry.content:
A SAP University Alliances está oferecendo o curso Business Processes Open Lecture 2025/26, uma oportunidade exclusiva para estudantes conhecerem na prática como funcionam os principais processos empresariais com o suporte do SAP.

📘 O curso tem 60 horas de duração e combina teoria e prática para oferecer uma visão completa dos processos de negócio em ação.
✅ E o melhor: ao final, você ainda terá a chance de realizar um exame oficial de certificação SAP!

🗓 Período: 30 de outubro de 2025 a 31 de março de 2026
🔗 Inscreva-se gratuitamente: https://imsap.co/6042Ag4Qn

entry.title: Enhancements to SAP Community - September 2025
entry.content:
• New Standards for Tags and Labels
  • <code> tag
  • Table of Contents (TOC)
  • Dismissible global banner
  • Glow/Dark Mode Fixes
  • Creation Date Filter on Feeds

We have been busy lately, and didn't only launch new developer forums this week, but we also released a few other features. 

New Standards for Tags and Labels 

We are setting limitations for the number of SAP Managed Tags, user tags, and labels that members can add to blog posts, questions, discussions, and documents. With these new standards, members will only be able to add ten of each type – meaning a maximum of ten SAP Managed Tags, ten user tags, and ten labels per piece of content. 

By setting these limitations, we’ll make it easier for members to find relevant content that interests them – as excessive tagging and labeling causes confusion in feeds and may frustrate members who receive notifications for posts that don’t match their expectations. Too many tags can also make it difficult for members to identify what a question is actually about, or if a blog post contains information that appeals to them. That’s why fewer tags are better – and why these new limitations have become necessary. 

Adding the right mix of SAP Managed Tags, user tags, and labels helps members locate what they want, so it’s important to understand what these selections represent – and equally important to be disciplined when picking them. 

SAP Managed Tags come from the official list of SAP offerings, as shown here. Every blog post, question, discussion, and document require at least one SAP Managed Tag for publication. As a best practice, we recommend no more than three of these tags. It is possible to subscribe to an SAP Managed Tag so that you will receive notifications of new content about that product.

Complementing SAP Managed Tags are user tags. These tags are created by the users themselves. User tags aren’t tied to any official list, so members have flexibility when coming up with these additional tags. 

We’re setting a maximum of ten for labels as well.  
Members can subscribe to a label to get notifications of new content associated with that label.

While a minimum of one SAP Managed Tag is mandatory for most content types, user tags and labels are generally optional – although a single label may also be mandatory for certain groups/boards. If you attempt to add more than ten, you’ll receive an error message when attempting to publish, and you’ll need to reduce the number before you can post the content. 

Note that these changes won’t impact existing content, so if you’ve been in the habit of adding dozens of tags and labels to content you’ve published in the past, you won’t need to go back and trim anything. But if you do try to make changes to this content (such as to correct a typo that you notice in an old blog post), you will need to make sure the post doesn’t exceed the maximum number of tags and/or labels. The system won’t let you update old content unless it meets the new standards for tagging and labeling. 

By applying SAP Managed Tags, user tags, and labels effectively (and judiciously), you’ll ensure that your content finds the right audience. Limiting the choices, to keep content more focused, will help your posts perform better, draw proper attention, and create a better experience for all.  



<code> tag

We have added the ability to use the <code> tag for inline code elements. 
The <code> HTML element displays its contents styled in a colored monospaced font to indicate that the text is a short fragment of code in the body of a post. 
For longer pieces of code, please continue to use the "Insert/Edit code sample" functionality of the editor. 

To use the <code> tag, you need to open the HTML/Source code editor from the toolbar: 

Next, you add the <code> tag around the inline code fragment you would like to share, or highlight in your post: 

The published version of the post will look like this:


Table of Contents (TOC)

We have also added the ability to add a Table of Contents (TOC) to both blog posts and documents (Knowledge Base articles). 
To use the Table of Contents functionality, you start by writing/adding your text in the editor after which you click the new "Table of Contents" button in the toolbar: 



Clicking the button will open a "Manage Table of Contents" pop-up which will give you a preview of the TOCs, including an overview over the TOC options: 

After clicking "Save", you will see a new "Table of Contents" menu at the top of the editor. Clicking this will open the "Manage Table of Contents" pop-up any time you need to access it: 

The TOCs in the final published post will look like this: 

 

Dismissible global banner

You asked if we could make the global banners dismissible, which we did. 
Clicking the "x" in the banner will now remove the banner, until a new banner is added. 



There will still be some areas of the community where the banners cannot be removed, for instance in our "Archived Content" area, where we have permanent banners informing users that content there is set to read-only. 


Glow/Dark Mode Fixes

Various Glow (new design) and Dark mode fixes were released this month as well.

For instance:

  • the Label widget has been hidden in some boards
  • the word ‘Board’ has been removed from the top of feeds to allow for the content to be moved up
  • Spacing around headers in posts have been fixed

Creation Date Filter on Feeds

A ‘Creation Date’ sorting option has been added on the various feeds to allow for easier sorting of the various posts. This is the default sorting of all feeds:

entry.title: 🟡 Fun for Week 2: Petoberfest 🐱🐶🐵🐷🐻🐸🐔🐴🦬🦎🐠🦜🐧🐌🐛
entry.content:
Welcome to Petoberfest, a tradition of Devtoberfest when you get a chance to show off your beloved pet hamster, cat, iguana, dog or whatever your pet is.

  • 👉Post a picture of your pet.
  • 👉Do not have a living, breathing pet? Upload a picture of your favorite neighbor's pet, or your favorite stuffed animal, or your favorite zoo animal, or any animal that tickles your fancy. Just participate!
  • 👉You can also upload a picture of you participating in any animal welfare activity (more on World Animal Day, below).

Here's my dog, Pepper, begging for food and enjoying a day at the beach.

   

IMPORTANT: We will award badges on the Monday after each week starting week 2, meaning Oct. 13, 20, and 27. You have until the end of Devtoberfest, EOD on Oct. 24 to submit your images.

It wouldn't be anything without AI

And just to make it a little bit more interesting, upload a picture of your pet, then use the picture with any generative AI tool to create your pet doing something fun: like ....

  • Doing your SAP programming work
  • Flying to save the day
  • Sipping a pina colada on the beach
  • ... or whatever you think of.

Be creative, in what your pet is doing, as well as the style of the image.

Here's Pepper expressing her love for SAP Build and helping me create my Devtoberfest Cryptic Crossword (she really does help me).

But I'm sure you can be much more creative.

World Animal Day

Petoberfest coincides with World Animal Day (Oct. 4), which "exists to raise the status of animals and improve welfare standards around the globe". 

According to the World Animal Day group in Cheltenham, Gloucestershire::

It’s a day for all animal lovers near and far.  Through organised events, big and small,  we raise awareness of how animals are treated globally. We rally together organisations, children’s groups, schools, clubs, companies, communities and individuals to show we care deeply about animals.

One way you can show you care about animals is to post a picture of your pet, or a picture of any activity you participate in to help the welfare of animals.

Point, Points, Points

Everyone who posts images of their pets will receive 1000 points toward the Devtoberfest grand prize.

So post today, and comment and like the other community members' posts.

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: New Enhancements, Developers Forums and Kick-off Event for SAP TechEd!
entry.content:
The month of September is over, but let’s take time to give a shoutout for all the great things this month brought to our SAP Community! More than 10 new platform features and enhancements, fresh new Blog Badges, the comeback of Developer Forums, and insightful content from our members. We’ve also hit a new milestone with 50K YouTube subscribers, and we would like to show our gratitude to everyone who continues to contribute and grow with us.

And to give you even more inspiration and reasons to connect with other members, we are celebrating and sharing all the information about the start of Devtoberfest and announcements for SAP TechEd on Tour (including the opportunity to become Community Talk Speaker for SAP TechEd on Tour in Bangalore!).

Read more below to find out what’s happening in and around SAP Community!

Featured Content

Simplified Journey with ALM and Integrated Toolchain Themes

Whether you are beginner or looking to reinforce your knowledge about SAP Cloud ALM, this step-by-step post by SAP´s @lealmeida, will for sure give you all the core features, background on integrated toolchain comprising powerful solutions and possible outcomes. Additionally, this content includes SAP Activate Methodology, to provide structured guidance for implementing SAP solutions effectively. Full of great resources, we highly encourage you to read, try and share your achievements in the comments!

Read the blog post 

Migrating from SAP PO to SAP Integration Suite (CPI) 

The process of migrating from SAP Process Orchestration (PO) to SAP Integration Suite (CPI), sometimes can be very tricky. But, in this step-by-step guide written by @Praveen_Kumar_Beera, you will learn how to connect SAP PO to SAP Cloud Connector, add it in SAP Integration Suite, and import message mappings along with dependent objects such as Imported Archives and Function Libraries. Beyond the technical shift, he made sure to explain how migrating is also an opportunity to modernize integration landscapes, adopt cloud-first patterns, and leverage the flexibility of SAP BTP.  

Read the blog post 

New feature in SAP BTP cockpit 

SAP´s @annikarossel, brought great news with the introduction of Favorites and Recent new feature for the SAP BTP cockpit. Providing faster and efficient access to important resources from everywhere in the cockpit, the main goal is to help you grow your productivity across various accounts, applications and services. Make sure to check the tutorial videos in the blog post, search where you can find these new buttons and give your feedback via the shell bar icon in the cockpit or join the user research survey.

Read the blog post 

SAP TechEd Expert Playlist 

TechEd is right around the corner, and the best way to prepare is organizing yourself to attend the sessions with topics that you are most passionate about. @Marla-Schweiki, SAP community member since 2018 and that has recently joined SAP Mentors program, prepared her Expert Playlist including all the themes and speakers in her favorites list. Be sure to check her selection and get some inspiration to make the most out of your time in Berlin!

Read the blog post 

Community News 

New searching Beta

If you ever struggled on finding a specific topic, event or user on SAP Community platform, we think you probably will enjoy the new Searching Beta feature. Powered by Coveo, this option you can select on the search bar and offers enhanced filtering and federated results across multiple repositories, including SAP.com, SAP Store, and SAP Support Portal There are also new menus that let you filter by specific products and SAP Managed Tags. You can either search for available products and tags or select multiple options. Additionally, the members request has been heard and now it is also possible to filter questions by status (answered, solved, and open). Try the new beta search for yourself, explore around and give your feedback on the comments inside the blog post here.  

Update on Rules of Engagement

Being an active member inside the SAP Community, also comes with the responsibility of following the rules and collaborating for a safe and enjoyable experience for everyone. In September the rules were updated to bring more clarification on participation etiquette, guidelines on publishing content and information on user profile. One of the most important is Article 3, that now has been revised to define what is “Unacceptable Content,” aligning with the EU’s Digital Services Act (DSA), and clarifies that job opportunities and postings are no longer permitted in the SAP Community. Please, we highly recommend reading the whole document here and putting effort into following the rules.  

New blog badges

In recognition of all our community bloggers, the full set of blogger badges is now live! If you are an active content creator, you have probably already seen this update and received a notification on your new badge. With milestones ranging from 1 to 30 content published, SAP´s @CaroleighDeneen explained on her latest blog post all the details on the progression set. If you’d like to get involved with blogging, start by taking our community tutorial and familiarize yourself with ours moderation policy for blogging.  

New developers Forums

Many of the members have been looking forward to this and our SAP Community team is thrilled to announce the launch of Developer Forums. Covering topics like ABAP (classic and cloud), AI, SAP CAP, Data & Analytics, HANA, Fiori/UI5, Integration, and Tooling, this is the new home for our developers and technical audience. Perhaps, the forums include threaded replies, a more compact feed for faster browsing, and a filter that many of you have been waiting for: “No answers”. The Developer Forums will be running as a pilot for 3 months, SAP will refine the experience based on feedback, so now is the best time to join. So, make sure to read more details on @AnnePetteroe post about the new feature and use the comment section to tell us what you think!  

More Enhancements to SAP Community

As you probably noticed by now, September was remarkable for the number of new enhancements in SAP Community. To make our members experience more smooth and complete, we are happy to launch: 

  • New Standards for Tags and Labels - Enables only 10 SAP Managed Tags, user tags and ten labels per piece of content.  
  • <code> tag - Ability to inline <code> HTML element in the body of a post, which will be displayed its contents styled in a colored monospaced font.  
  • Table of Contents (TOC) - Functionality that allows to add the Table of Contents for blog posts and documents (Knowledge Base articles).  This button will open a “Managed Table of Contents” to give you a preview and options overview. 
  • Dismissible Global Banner - The team heard our members request and now is possible to find the button “X” in the banner, which will be removed until a new banner is added. Perhaps, some areas in the platform the banner cannot be removed (e.g., "Archived Content" area, where we have permanent banners informing users that content there is set to read-only).  
  • Glow/Dark Mode Fixes – Both modes were fixed and now the Label widget has been hidden in some boards, the “Board” word has also been removed from the top of the feed (allowing the content to be moved up) and “spacing” around headers in post is fixed. 
  • Date Filter on Feeds - Creation Date’ sorting option has been added to all feeds, making it easier to organize and view posts by when they were created. 

Check more details and images description of each one of these new features here!  

YouTube channel reached 50K 

One of our main social channels has just reached a new milestone! The SAP Community YouTube channel now has more than 50k subscribers. We would like to say thank you to each one of our members who is active in our community and always engages with our videos. You are the reason we keep creating and doing our best to deliver great content. And if you’re not yet aware of our channel, watch now here, explore our playlists, and subscribe to get notifications every time we upload another cool video! 

Events

Devtoberfest is here!

Built for developers by developers, the Devtoberfest by SAP TechEd has officially started! This first week is full of amazing sessions about ABAP, Tooling & Frontend, Integration, Data & AI, CAP and many fun activities (For more information about the Scavenger Hunt, check Daniel´s post). If you are actively participating, don´t forget to earn your points for the Grand Prize competition, by taking the validation tutorials here. Check the latest blog post by @KevinR for more details on the list of all the points you can earn for each activity. Don´t miss this chance to participate!  

Reminder of TechEd Agenda Builder

The end of the year for our SAP Community also means that we are getting closer to TechEd. Once again, we would like to remind everyone to take the time to build your agenda. Available for both onsite or online attendees, this tool allows you to mix and match the sessions with topics you are most looking forward to watching. Remember: you need a Full Conference Pass to book Hands-On Workshops and there is a maximum of 2 allowed per attendee. Act now because they fill up fast! Read here more details on how to do it.  

The SAP TechEd on Tour is coming to Sydney!

Calling all our folks from Australia, because the SAP TechEd on Tour is coming to Sydney this year! From the 12 until 14 of November, the ICC Sydney will be hosting one of the biggest learning and networking events for our SAP community. Tracks covering the biggest trend topics, Developer Garage, the presence of SAP Mentors and Champions and much more. Look on this post for more details And if you are part of the Sydney Location group or are planning on visiting the city, make sure to take part!

Call for Community Talk Speakers for SAP TechEd on Tour in Bangalore

Do you love exchanging insights and experience in SAP technologies with others? Then this is your opportunity to become a Community Talk speaker.  For our upcoming SAP TechEd on Tour in Bangalore, happening in November 25-25, we are offering slots for a 20-minute session to showcase your expertise. This is a great opportunity to collaborate and engage with developers, business leaders and expand your reach. The selected speakers get a “Lecture-Only” ticket to attend SAP TechEd (travel and expenses are not covered by SAP). October 10. Is the deadline to submit the application and the notification of acceptance will be sent out on October 17. The final presentation submission for review is on November 10. (but if you are not planning to give a presentation, that is completely fine as well). SAP´s @MynynaChau gave some details on her blog post, make sure to read and find more details on the Topics to Consider and the guide on How to Apply. 

Highlights of SAP Inside Tracks

Finally, we would like to recognize the amazing effort our SAP Community has put into the SAP Inside Track´s that happened in September. Congratulations to all event organizers and volunteers at SAP Inside Track Philadelphia, SAP Inside Track Hamburg, SAP Inside Track Porto, SAP SIT RS (Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil) . and many other meetups around the world. Stay tuned to our YouTube channel, where we’ll soon be uploading exclusive content to give you a closer look and inspire you to attend upcoming events in your area!

entry.title: Devtoberfest 2025 - What is Happening Week 2
entry.content:
Hi everybody, the first week of Devtoberfest is over and we are heading strong into Week 2. This blog post should give you a good overview on what is happening in our second week of Devtoberfest.

Sessions for Week 2 (Oct 6 - Oct 10):

All sessions for Week 2 can be found in our Session Catalogue: https://community.sap.com/t5/devtoberfest/eb-p/devtoberfest-events

entry.title: Responsible Vibe Coding Tutorial: Building a Meeting Room CAP App
entry.content:
🎯What is Vibe Coding?

Vibe coding means collaborating with AI assistants to build apps step by step, entirely through natural language prompts. Instead of writing everything yourself, you “vibe” with AI to generate, refine, and optimize code.

This tutorial shows how to build a Meeting Room Booking app with CAP + AI Core, entirely through prompts — from schema to service, business logic, AI integration, and a simple UI.

 

Quick prerequisites

  • VS Code + Cline extension (or your Claude integration)
  • Node.js (v18+) and @SAP/cds-dk (CAP CLI)
  • SAP BTP account with AI Core (for production); we include a dev fallback.
  • Git repo and .clinerules set up (recommended)

Step 0 — Plan first (Cline Plan mode)

Always start with a short Plan prompt to the AI (Cline Plan mode). Example plan template:

Plan:

- Goal: Add a MeetingRoom CAP service with Book/Cancel/Search and a recommendRoom AI action.

- Acceptance criteria: CDS created + seed data; BookService exposing actions; recommendRoom returns top-3 rooms with reasons; endpoints testable via curl.

- Assumptions: No auth (dev), timezone = UTC, single-tenant.

- Edge cases: overlapping bookings, zero-capacity rooms, invalid room IDs.

- Tests: curl examples for create/search/recommend and a UI smoke test.

Part 1: Setting Up the Environment

🎤The Prompt:

Set up a new CAP project for a meeting room booking system.

💡What Happened:
The AI guided installation, created a new CAP project, and initialized dependencies.

Generated Commands:

npm install -g @SAP/cds-dk

cds init meeting-vibe

cd meeting-vibe

npm install

Key Learning: Always start with a clean project skeleton before vibing features.

Part 2: Creating the Data Model

🎤The Prompt:

Create a data model with Rooms and Bookings. Rooms have capacity, location, amenities, and availability. Bookings track user, room, start/end times, and status. Include seed data.

💡What Happened:
The AI generated the core CDS schema and sample CSV seed files.

📂Generated Schema:

namespace vibe.meetings;

 

entity Rooms : cuid, managed {

  name      : String(111) not null;

  location  : String(111);

  capacity  : Integer;

  amenities : String;

  available : Boolean default true;

}

 

entity Bookings : cuid, managed {

  room    : Association to Rooms;

  userId  : String(36);

  start   : Timestamp;

  end     : Timestamp;

  purpose : String(255);

  status  : String(20) default 'CONFIRMED';

}

Key Learning: A single domain-level prompt is enough to generate a correct schema with relationships.

Part 3: Adding the Service Layer

🎤The Prompt:

Expose the Rooms and Bookings as a BookingService with actions: bookRoom, cancelBooking, searchAvailableRooms, and recommendRoom.

💡What Happened:
The AI produced a full CDS service definition.

📂Generated Service Definition:

service BookingService {

  entity Rooms as projection on vibe.meetings.Rooms;

  entity Bookings as projection on vibe.meetings.Bookings;

 

  action bookRoom(roomId: UUID, userId: String, start: Timestamp, end: Timestamp, purpose: String) returns Bookings;

  action cancelBooking(bookingId: UUID) returns String;

  function searchAvailableRooms(start: Timestamp, end: Timestamp, minCapacity: Integer) returns array of Rooms;

  action recommendRoom(start: Timestamp, end: Timestamp, attendees: Integer, prefs: String) returns array of {

    roomId: UUID;

    score: Decimal(5,2);

    reason: String;

  };

}

Key Learning: The AI can infer the exact CRUD operations and business functions you need if you describe them clearly.

Part 4: Business Logic Implementation

🎤The Prompt:

Implement handlers for bookRoom, cancelBooking, and searchAvailableRooms in JavaScript with validation and error handling.

💡What Happened:
The AI generated a srv/book-service.js with full logic for booking, cancelling, and searching.

📂Example Implementation:

this.on('bookRoom', async (req) => {

  const { roomId, userId, start, end, purpose } = req.data;

  if (new Date(start) >= new Date(end)) req.error(400, 'Invalid time range');

  const overlap = await SELECT.one.from(Bookings).where`room=${roomId} AND start < ${end} AND end > ${start}`;

  if (overlap) req.error(409, 'Room already booked');

  const booking = await INSERT.into(Bookings).entries({ room_ID: roomId, userId, start, end, purpose });

  return booking;

});

Key Learning: When you ask for validation + error handling, the AI adds production-quality safeguards.

Part 5: AI-Powered Recommendations

🎤The Prompt:

Add AI integration with SAP AI Core to suggest the best rooms. Include a fallback heuristic when AI Core is not configured.

💡What Happened:
The AI created srv/ai-recommender.js, with both AI Core and fallback logic.

📂Example Snippet:

async recommendRooms({ start, end, attendees, prefs, rooms }) {

  if (!this.config.clientId) {

    return rooms.map(r => ({

      roomId: r.ID,

      score: r.capacity >= attendees ? 80 : 50,

      reason: `Capacity ${r.capacity} vs ${attendees}`

    })).slice(0,3);

  }

  // AI Core integration here...

}

Key Learning: Always request a fallback path — AI assistants can build graceful degradation into your app.

Part 6: Building a Simple UI

🎤The Prompt:

Create a simple SAP UI5 page with fields for start/end time, attendees, preferences, and a button to call recommendRoom. Show results in a table.

💡What Happened:
The AI created view/Main.view.xml with a table bound to the recommendation endpoint.

📂Example View Snippet:

<VBox>

  <DateTimePicker id="start"/>

  <DateTimePicker id="end"/>

  <Input id="attendees" placeholder="Attendees"/>

  <Input id="prefs" placeholder="Preferences"/>

  <Button text="Recommend" press=".onRecommend"/>

  <Table id="tblRooms">...</Table>

</VBox>

Key Learning: Even complex UI scaffolding can be generated quickly when you specify layout + bindings.

Part 7: Documentation & Testing

🎤The Prompt:

Create a TESTING_GUIDE.md with curl commands to test all service actions.

💡What Happened:
The AI wrote a full Markdown testing guide with:

  • curl for bookRoom, cancelBooking, searchAvailableRooms, recommendRoom
  • expected responses
  • error case examples

Key Learning: Ask for docs and tests explicitly — they are as important as code.

🎯Best Practices for Responsible Vibe Coding

  • Engineer > AI: Review, understand, and own every line.
  • Test Before You Trust: Validate edge cases with curl or UI.
  • Plan First: Use Cline Plan mode before big prompts.
  • Fallbacks Matter: Always ask AI to build dev-safe fallbacks.
  • Docs Are Not Optional: Generate and maintain documentation with prompts.

🏗️ What We Built Together

Through prompts alone, we created:

  • 📊Data Layer: Rooms & Bookings entities with seed data
  • 🔧Business Logic: Booking, cancellation, search with validations
  • 🤖AI Integration: Room recommendations with AI Core + fallback
  • 🎨UI: Simple SAP UI5 page for booking and recommendations
  • 📚Docs: A testing guide for backend and UI

🎉Congratulations!

You’ve just built a Meeting Room Booking CAP app by vibing with AI — responsibly. The secret: always combine AI’s speed with your engineering judgment.

📖Learn More

  • SAP CAP Documentation
  • SAP AI Core Documentation
  • Cline Extension

28 жовтня, 17:00-18:00 🔹 SAP Integration Suite - Monthly Update Жовтневі оновлення iPaaS: дизайн, розробка та управління integration flows і APIs

29 жовтня, 12:00-13:00 🔹 Sustainable Procurement SAP Ariba Sourcing: збір Scope 3 emissions data та sustainability foundation 📌 Три сесії для різних регіонів (12:00, 07:00, 18:00 EEST)

30 жовтня, 16:00-17:00 🔹 Boost Data-Driven Transformation Останні інновації в SAP Signavio для генерації actionable insights

30 жовтня, 18:00-19:00 🔹 SAP Fiori UX Guide - Part 2 SAP Build для AI-based розробки + ABAP development tools та extensibility сценарії

*Всі години вказані за київським часом (EEST)

Реєструйтесь вже зараз, посилання в назві вебкасту

entry.title: New Developer- and SAP-Technology Forums/Groups
entry.content:
Dear "Application Development and Automation" group members/subscribers, 

In case you haven't seen the general announcement post that went out earlier this week, this blog post is to inform you that we launched a pilot of new developer- and SAP-technology related forums/groups this week.

For you, this means that while the pilot runs, the "Application Development and Automation" group is set to read-only.
We would like to encourage you to go to our new developer forums/groups, if you would like to ask or answer questions, or publish blog posts, on development/technology-related topics. 

There are a number of different reasons why we would like to test these new forums/groups: 

  1. Since our platform migration last year, we have received feedback that you didn't know where to go to find topics like ABAP, Integration or UI5. With these new developer forums/groups, we hope we have made it easier for you to find the technology topics you are most interested in.

  2. We noticed that the discussion board in this group was used to ask development related-questions. Generally, everyone has been very helpful answering questions asked here. However, our interest groups are for having conversations with, and connecting to, like-minded people around shared interests. This is why these groups have discussion boards (= for conversations) and blog posts, instead of Q&As/forums. Therefore, when someone asks a question in the "Application Development and Automation" discussion board, it is not possible for the author to accept the right answer as a solution. This again means, that if someone with the same problem comes to the community to get help later on, they will not be able to see what the solution to the problem was.
    Which brings us to no. 3 below:

  3. Because answers to questions in discussion (conversation) boards won't have accepted solutions, we are also not able to give credit to, or celebrate, the members who took the time to help answer questions.

  4. With the new developer forums, authors can accept any answer as a correct solution, which means we will be able to bring back our topic expert leaderboards, and give proper credit to our members who answer questions.

  5. A new denser forum feed, with no preview of content, making it easier to scroll down the feed to look for the questions you can help answer: 


  6. New filter for "Questions with no answers". 
    This long-requested filter has now been added to all new Developers forums, so that you can find all questions with. no answers on a specific topic with one click: 
  7. We can now highlight important product announcements, or other valuable content, you shouldn't miss, around your favourite development topics by using the "Featured Topics" section for the individual topics.

  8. Better subscription management.
    You will now be able to subscribe to either all developer/SAP-technology related content, or drill down to and only subscribe to the specific parts that interest you the most:
    1. Developers https://community.sap.com/t5/developers/ct-p/developers - here you can subscribe to the whole category, this subscription sends you notifications on the platform and email notifications according to your account settings. 
    2. The individual groups, with both the Forums and Blog posts - here taking ABAP Cloud as an example: https://community.sap.com/t5/abap-cloud/gh-p/abap-cloud - here you have the same subscribe option as above. If you subscribe to content here, it will send you notifications on the platform and email notifications according to your account settings. 
    3. The individual group boards, ABAP Cloud Forum: https://community.sap.com/t5/abap-cloud-forum/bd-p/abap-cloudforum-board - here you have both the option to Subscribe and Subscribe to RSS Feed. The Subscribe option is the same as the two options above, and the RSS Feed is the one you are looking for. 
      You will find the same options for the blog posts boards as well: https://community.sap.com/t5/abap-cloud-blog-posts/bg-p/abap-cloudblog-board


If you missed the main announcement post, you can find more information in this What's New blog post. 

We hope you hop over to the new Developer groups to try them out 🙂 
If you have any feedback to us on the forums, you can provide it in the comments section on the What's New post linked above.

entry.title: New in SAP Profile: Your Recent Activity Feed
entry.content:
We’re excited to announce a new feature in the SAP Profile: the Recent Activity feed.

From now on, whenever you publish a blog post, answer a question, or engage in other activities in SAP Community, your contributions will automatically appear in a dedicated feed on your personal SAP Profile page.

In the screenshot below, the areas marked in red and green highlight the new features (the color boxes are only for illustration and not part of the actual design):

  • Red box: the new Recent Activity feed. It supports infinite scrolling, allowing you to explore your past activities without any limit.

  • Green box: the new Reputation section, which we will continue to enhance by adding data from additional SAP touchpoints over time.

The section highlighted in the green box also shows the newly introduced Reputation section. We will continue to expand this section and add data from other SAP touchpoints. 

Why this matters

Your SAP Profile is the central place where others can learn more about you, your expertise, and your community presence. With the new activity feed:

  • Your contributions shine – Every blog post, answer, or update you share becomes more visible.

  • Your expertise is easier to discover – Visitors to your profile can now quickly see your most recent activities.

  • Your profile feels more complete – It’s not just a static page anymore, but a living reflection of your engagement.

How it works

The feed updates in near real-time, powered by a new event-based architecture that our team built not only for this feature, but also as a foundation for future scenarios. Event-based systems are a powerful architectural pattern that allows us to deliver updates quickly and reliably — and you’ll see more benefits of this approach in upcoming enhancements.

To make the feed even more engaging, we’ve included images alongside the activity updates. This makes the stream more visually appealing, more useful, and easier to understand at a glance. While adding images added some complexity, the result is well worth it for the user experience.

Go ahead and check your SAP Profile today — your personal feed is already waiting for you!

entry.title: Can SAP’s Real-Time Analytics Redefine Decision-Making for the C-Suite?
entry.content:
The Changing Role of Leaders

Today’s CEOs and CTOs face more data than ever before. Numbers flow in from finance, supply chain, and customers. The challenge is not access. The challenge is speed. Leaders cannot wait days for reports. They need answers now.

Why Real-Time Matters

Traditional reporting works on past data. By the time insights reach the boardroom, the market may have moved. Real-time analytics flips this model. It brings live data from operations straight to decision-makers. A CEO can see global sales by region as they happen. A CTO can monitor system health before an outage hits.

How SAP Enables This

  • SAP HANA: stores and processes data in-memory for instant results.
  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC): gives live dashboards and predictive models.
  • Embedded Analytics: in S/4HANA allows leaders to view insights while working inside core processes.

These tools cut delays and remove the guesswork.

Practical Example

Imagine a manufacturer facing a sudden raw material shortage. Without real-time analytics, the CEO learns of it after a weekly report. With SAP, alerts appear the moment supply drops. Leaders can adjust sourcing, update prices, and inform partners—all within hours, not days.

Best Practices for the C-Suite

  • Ask sharper questions: Real-time data works best when leaders know what to track.
  • Balance speed with accuracy: Not all data needs live updates. Focus on what drives action.
  • Build trust in data: If executives doubt the system, they will fall back on instinct.

Challenges to Watch

Real-time analytics is powerful, but not simple. Common issues include:

  • Integrating data from multiple systems.
  • Ensuring security and access control.
  • Training leaders to read dashboards, not just slides.

The Bigger Picture

Real-time analytics does not replace leadership. It sharpens it. CEOs still need vision. CTOs still need strategy. SAP’s role is to provide clear, trusted signals so leaders can act without delay.

Engage Further

The question for the C-suite is simple: Are you ready to let real-time data guide your next move? If you want to explore practical steps, connect with experts, or join discussions in the SAP Community.

entry.title: Want to Earn More Badges? Let’s Discuss!
entry.content:
Healthy discourse is a critical component for any community, and our latest badge progression set is designed specifically for members who kick these conversations off by starting discussions. 

As with the other progression badges that we introduced recently, this set will contain five badges that will be awarded retroactively – meaning, if you’ve already initiated discussions in the community, you may get one or more badges tomorrow (Thursday, October 9). You’ll earn the first badge for the first discussion you started, the second for starting three discussions, the third for starting ten, and the fourth for starting twenty. If you’ve been especially chatty, you may even get the fifth badge – awarded for starting fifty discussions! 

If you’re unfamiliar with discussions in SAP Community, you’ll find several lively ones within our various groups. We have groups for locations around the world, fun activities (such as Devtoberfest), common interests (including the community’s very own Welcome Corner), and more. 

Unlike the Q&A boards (where members seek solutions to their problems), discussions generally focus on an open topic and allow other members to share their thoughts and opinions. There’s no right answer – just an invitation to participate in a friendly chat. 

If you’d like to start a discussion, first find a group that interests you. Click the big blue button near the top of the group’s page to join. You can’t miss it. (Note that some private groups may require that their owners approve your request to join, but you can join any public group right away with the click of the button.) 

If you try to start a discussion before joining a group, the option will be grayed out. 

 

Joining the group opens the option to start a discussion.  

 

While we understand that our badge enthusiasts may be eager to complete this new set quickly, please make sure that you only start discussions that are relevant to the corresponding group(s) in which you want to post – and that the discussions are meant to encourage group members to participate in the conversation. Starting an off-topic discussion may earn you a badge, but it won’t generate any interest. A group owner or curator may even opt to remove the discussion if it doesn’t fit the group’s purpose. Best to spend some time in a group to get to know it and its members before starting a discussion there. 

Once you’re comfortable with a group (and feel confident you can strike up appealing discussions in it), take advantage of the opportunity to earn badges from the new set. Or if you’re already active in groups (with several discussions to your credit), you may earn one or more badges when we introduce the new set tomorrow. 

Want to know how many badges from this set you’re entitled to? Here’s what you need to do.  

Log in to SAP Community, then select “My content.” 

 

Scroll down to the “Private Stats” section of your content page and look for the “Discussions Started” entry. That number will help you determine how many badges coming your way tomorrow. For example, for the member below, he can expect badges for starting one, three, and ten discussions – as his fourteen discussions are more than enough to earn him the first three badges in the set. He’ll need to be a little more active in group discussions to earn the last two (for twenty and fifty discussions, respectively). Still, he’s well on his way to completing the set! 

We’ll need a few hours to assign the badges tomorrow, and we’ll award them one at a time from the lowest to highest. Our friend above can expect three notifications (one for each badge that he earned, beginning with the badge for starting his first discussion), and you can expect one or more yourself if you’ve been actively starting discussions in the community. (If your badges haven’t shown up by Friday the 10th, make sure to log out and in again.) 

Don’t forget: These badges are meant to thank the members who take the time to make positive contributions to SAP Community. Answer a question, write a blog post that educates other members, leave a kudo on content that you enjoy, begin a friendly discussion. Each of those actions helps create a healthier, happier community – and can earn you badges that show our appreciation.

entry.title: 🟡 Fun for Week 3: Puzzles, Puzzles, Puzzles 🧩📝
entry.content:
As we do each Devtoberfest, we have published an all-new and improved SAP Cryptic Crossword. And ... we have 3 additional puzzles -- including new types of puzzles -- to challenge you even more.

SAP Cryptic Crossword Puzzle

The centerpiece of the 2025 puzzles is again the SAP Cryptic Crossword. Just go to the crossword tutorial and you can complete it there: https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/devtoberfest2025-sap-crossword.html

The tutorial has some guidance on how to solve cryptic crosswords, but feel free to ask for help in this blog post.

👉TIP: Best to print out the grid and clues, solve it, and then enter the answers in the tutorial.

There is also a bonus puzzle where you have to take some of the letters in the completed puzzle and derive the name of 2 of our esteemed Developer Advocates: https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/devtoberfest2025-sap-crossword-bonus.html

How an ex-CEO of SAP saved the day

I'm going to tell a story about embracing failure, laughing at yourself, and learning from your mistakes. But ...

🚨🚨🚨SPOILER ALERT - I will spoil one of the answers of the SAP Cryptic Crossword, so skip this section if you don't want to have that clue spoiled.

When I first started creating the puzzle, I had this area of the puzzle that needed a clue/answer:

Since the puzzle focused on developers, and I was quite familiar with SAP Build Apps functions, I thought of the function CIEL(), which rounds a number to the next integer. Perfect! I even had a really good clue.

Command to round up horrific lice

 Well, I gave the puzzle to @qmacro to test. And besides being able to complete it in what seemed like 5 minutes, he found an embarrassing error -- I HAD MISSPELLED THE NAME OF THE FUNCTION!! The function was CEIL() not CIEL()!

I literally cursed out loud when I saw the mistake 😠.

Well, it was quite difficult to somehow make the function's real name fit and to move the puzzle around. So I searched for another answer that would fit. And the first thing I thought of was BILL, as in the name of our former CEO (also a word contained in some of our business processes). Bill McDermott was the longest-serving CEO during my tenure at SAP.

And that's how Bill McDermott saved my puzzle.

Scramble Puzzles

I am a big reader of Games magazine, since high school. And one of the simpler but fun puzzles is one where you have to find 10 words by taking each one's clue, removing one letter and then rearranging the remaining letters to form a new word. And then you have to figure out the common denominator of all those words.

Here's one from a recent issue. Try it.

So I decided to create my own for Devtoberfest, one related to programming languages and one related to the Event-Based Processes CodeJam that I do with my good colleague @ajmaradiaga.

  • Scramble, Programming Languages: https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/devtoberfest2025-fun-scramble-languages.html
  • Scramble, Event-Based Processes CodeJam: https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/devtoberfest2025-fun-scramble-codejam.html

Admission: Not that difficult to make 

It is pretty easy to create these puzzles. You take an online Scrabble word finder app -- I use this one, https://scrabblewordfinder.org/. 

Let's say you are doing a puzzle on fruit, and you start with a possible answer like apple. You search for any word with those letters plus any other letter by adding a question mark.

Then you look for a word that looks the least like apple. Here, I would say upleap. And that's all you have to do.

entry.title: Protecting the integrity of the community content
entry.content:
Generative AI tools can be powerful aids when used thoughtfully, offering speed and inspiration, but they can also produce misleading or inaccurate results if applied without real expertise. Their value comes from being trained on years of human-created knowledge, yet that is also why our community must be careful in how they are applied.

Workflows are shifting as users adopt more efficient ways to get the information needed to complete their tasks.
But one thing remains constant: people come to our community because they trust the answers, posts, and discussions written by fellow members. To preserve that trust and ensure our content remains reliable, we need clear, shared guidelines on the responsible use of generative AI within our community. 

The slippery slope

At first glance, protecting content integrity by banning all GenAI-assisted content generation may seem a simple choice. But that would ignore the fact that GenAI can be a powerful aid in creating content (it even played a role in drafting this). The trick is developing guidelines that lets users take advantage of these tools to enhance their productivity. Consider this scenario:

About 75% of traffic in our community happens in the Q&A/Forums section, where people come looking for solutions to specific problems. The traditional workflow has looked something like this:

  • You run into a problem and start with a Google search.
  • From the results, you open a handful of promising pages, read through them, and piece together enough information to solve your issue or at least get enough of a hint.
  • If that doesn’t work, you post a question. If your post doesn’t include enough detail, there’s a back-and-forth in the comments until someone can provide a solid answer. That process may take time.

With generative AI, the workflow shifts:

  • You may still search as before.
  • More often, you open your preferred generative AI tool, start with a quick prompt, invest more time in writing a prompt if needed, and engage in a rapid back-and-forth until you get a usable answer or enough direction to move forward. In practice, the tool is drawing on nearly all available content at once.
  • If you still don’t get what you need, only then might you open a new question or discussion thread.

With this as a standard workflow now and access to many geneartive AI tools, it is tempting to take any unanswered question, paste it into a GenAI tool, copy the response and paste in the answer. The danger here is if the person posting the answer doesn’t actually know if it is correct or not.
This creates two problems if the answer is wrong:

  1. the original poster will believe it to be correct, try it, wasting their time and diminishing the perceived value of the community.
  2. if incorrect data remains in the community, it will be scraped by the generative AI models, used in their training or RAG systems, decreasing the quality of answers (until it is removed).

This community exists to share knowledge and experience between real people. AI tools cannot ensure accuracy, provide verifiable sources, or account for the nuances of real-world problem solving. Allowing AI-authored posts without the author verifying the content risks:

  • Spreading incorrect or misleading information.
  • Eroding the trust between members.
  • Diminishing the long-term value of our content.

Acceptable use of generative AI tools

You may use GenAI tools to help you plan, structure, or clarify your writing, as long as the final result reflects your own thoughts and tone.

Examples include:

  • Outlining your post or drafting a structure to build upon
  • Checking spelling, translation, or accessibility
  • Getting suggestions for phrasing, while keeping your own wording and perspective

If a generative AI tool meaningfully shaped your post (anything beyond the examples above like rewriting full paragraphs or producing a significant amount of the text), please disclose it by adding the predefined "GenAI Assisted Content" label, or include a short note such as “This post was assisted by GenAI.” For content where it's not possible to add a user tag, e.g., answers to questions and comments, you must include this statement: "This post was assisted by GenAI."

Doing so will provide the transparency needed to maintain credibility in the community.

A predefined "GenAI Assisted Content" label can now be found throughout the community: 


Unacceptable use of generative AI tools

Posts that are primarily generated, rewritten, or reworded by AI are not allowed.

Examples include:

  • Submitting AI-generated answers to questions or forum threads
  • Submitting AI-generated articles or comments to content as your own
  • Using AI to “polish” a post so heavily that it loses your natural voice
  • Copying or pasting AI text directly from a prompt
  • Publishing content with little or no personal input or factual verification

Moderators may remove posts that read as machine-written or lack personal insight, regardless of the author’s stated intent.

A TLDR summary (intentionally at the end) or guiding principle is:

Anything you post in the community should represent your thinking, experience, and knowledge.
AI may assist you in the creation, but it cannot substitute for your voice. 
To keep your trust and add continual value to our members we must remain a community of people, for people, in our shared world of technology. 

The complete generative AI guidelines for the SAP Community can be found in our Welcome Corner group.
